tl;dr last post: this film is brilliant. Please give as much praise as possible so the industry might continue making things like this. Most of us are confused organisms who want to be presented with the unknown. Whatever the plot and characters were doing, the ideas alone held the film up--and the latter were pretty damn good.

I'll be frank, and it's only because I adored this movie so much that I feel comfortable putting out a slight critique. There were some flaws, some of the emotion was a bit hammy (although Nolan is hardly famous for his human touch) and some of the plot did feel a bit random. However, even though many critics savaged it.... I fucking loved this film and I cried like a baby during certain scenes. As a hardened sci-fi reader, this is the film I've been waiting for, and I feel it's the film I would've made, if I was a lot smarter, had $200million and amazing directing skills. It's like other space films, except it goes beyond the point where they would normally stop and leave things unexplained: this goes to all the levels a sci-fi fan wants. The space travel is astounding, jaw-dropping, terrifying, beautiful (wouldn't normally use such cliche adjectives but... damn). The emotional connection with his daughter moved me to the point of tears. At no point did I feel let down, because it just kept pushing and going to new places. I think the dust needs to settle a bit, because for what it was intended to be, it's a masterpiece. I just know this will end up being one of the films I watch repeatedly for the next 50 years. God damn, I'm so happy it was finally made. This film just fills a void in cinema where a perfect, Interstellar-shaped hole existed. Nolan is a hero of our time.

Yet another hilarious space flick that makes up its own space physics. Had to bail after MM flies into a black hole and survives. Evidently, what would happen if one actually did attempt to enter a black hole is when one approached the event horizon, the gravity of the black hole would begin pulling one apart, bit by bit. As one entered the black hole, one would be separated into smaller and smaller pieces, like a string of macaroni. Now, if they had showed that, I would have stuck with the movie.

Here's my take. A valiant attempt to take on a big block buster sci-fi movie about quantum physics and deep human themes of love and humanity. However, I think Nolan bit off more than he could chew with this one. After viewing, I kept thinking this film was over indulgent in nearly every way. The characters were weak, plot rushed (terrible flow), overly melodramatic, and ultimately disappointing in its scope. What he lacked in those key areas he tried to make up with state of the art special effects and a suffocation of scientific information (there's nothing wrong with that in general but it's just foolish to try and cram that level of cosmology and quantum physics education into a 3 hour mainstream movie). To me, Nolan is like the Starbucks of film making; on the surface his style and choice of themes seem intellectual and authentic. However, under that surface is just a watered down, massed produced corporate product under the guise of quality. I don't think this is a masterpiece in the same way "2001" or "Alien" were. Just like the album "The Wall" by Pink Floyd or the film "Apocalypse Now" by Francis Ford Coppola, this movie aimed way too high without hitting the mark.

I want to say sorry for being THAT guy but I feel deeply offended by comments I see regarding religion :). If you are willing to listen to my opinion without spreading hate then click read more. I am happy to accept any of your RESPCTFUL arguments. :) May I say that I do not study religion nor do I know a whole lot about others. I do however believe in God for various reasons. I am a Muslim so I am speaking in my religions point of view :). Many people may say that religion and science will never mix but I say and believe different. I would also like to clarify that there are also many things said in Islam (and other religions) that science cannot answer, therefore they are dismissed and considered inaccurate so I will not cover that (I'll leave it to the experts xD). I just want to clear up that the Qur'an is historically proven to have been the oldest holy book that has been preserved and kept the same over 1400+ years (The time of it's revelation). What I'm saying here is that the Bible, Torah etc. were changed over time. That is a FACT. Here is the most known example of science in the Qur'an. The birth of a human: The miracle of man's creation is emphasised in many verses. Some of the information within these verses is so detailed that it was impossible for anyone living in the 7th century to have known it. Examples of these are as follows: 1. Man is not created from the entire semen, but only a very small portion of it (sperm). 2. It is the male that determines the sex of the baby. 3. The human embryo adheres to the mother's uterus like a leech. 4. The embryo develops in three dark regions in the uterus. Let's pick out verses from the Qur'an that mention these. 1. Sperm undertake a journey into the mother's body until they reach the ovum. Only a thousand out of 250 million sperm succeed in reaching the ovum. At the end of this five-minute race, the ovum, half the size of a grain of salt, will let only one of the sperms in. That is, the substance of man is not the whole semen, but only a small part of it. This is explained in the Surat al-Qiyama as follows: Does man reckon he will be left uncontrolled [without purpose]? Was he not once a drop of ejected semen? (Qur'an, 75:36-37) 2. Until fairly recently, it was thought that a baby's sex was determined by the mother's cells. Or at least, it was believed that the sex was determined by the male and female cells together. But, we are given different information in the Qur'an, where it is stated that masculinity or femininity is created out of "a drop of sperm which has been ejected." He has created both sexes, male and female from a drop of semen which has been ejected. (Qur'an, 53:45-46) Was he not a drop of ejaculated sperm, then a blood-clot which He created and shaped, making from it both sexes, male and female? (Qur'an, 75:37-39) The developing disciplines of genetics and molecular biology have scientifically validated the accuracy of this information given by the Qur'an. It is now understood that sex is determined by the sperm cells from the male, and that the female has no role in this process. The Qur'an even talks about the development of a foetus! [We] then formed the drop into a clot and formed the clot into a lump and formed the lump into bones and clothed the bones in flesh; and then brought him into being as another creature. Blessed be Allah, the Best of Creators! (Qur'an, 23:14) (All Information above is taken from http://miraclesofthequran.com/scientific_57.html) Now to Stephen Hawking's theory. In the Qur'an, which was revealed fourteen centuries ago at a time when the science of astronomy was still primitive, the expansion of the universe was described in the following terms: And it is We Who have constructed the heaven with might, and verily, it is We Who are steadily expanding it. (Qur'an, 51:47) The word "heaven," as stated in the verse above, is used in various places in the Qur'an. It is referring to space and the wider universe. Here again, the word is used with this meaning, stating that the universe "expands." The Arabic word "moosiaaoona" in the term "inna lamoosiaaoona," translated into English as "it is We Who are steadily expanding it", comes from the verb "evsea," meaning "to expand." The prefix "la" emphasises the following name or title and adds a sense of "to a great extent." This expression therefore means "We expand the sky or the universe to a great extent." This is the very conclusion that science has reached today. All this was known to Muhammad (Peace be upon him) 15 hundred years ago! All things we have recently discovered. I think my biggest complaint about this movie is that I sort of expected everything .. there was nothing that was surprising .. it tried too hard to be grounded in realistic physics while simultaneously venturing into a dimension where our scientific reality might be almost irrelevant. If it where a movie which tried to explore the anomalies of the universe in a more imaginative manner without being tied down too much by the technicalities ... it would've been much more inspirational. But, execution of the movie was perfect, visually stunning and very immersive .. just didn't leave me thinking about it too much.

It is a great tribute to 2001: a space odyssey, it is a really challenging movie, it plays with your mind and imagination to the maximum degree.It is about love, hope, dreams, faith, family and evolution of humanity - not only in technological sense but in emotional sense as well. If you're sc-fi or movie fan in general you're going to be blown away and it is something to experience. Sure it has some logical issues and you have to suspend your disbelief but it is a rewarding movie and despite it being derivative, it is still unbelievable seeing the idea this big from someone's mind translated onto a big screen. 4.5/5

commentText: I'm afraid this will be another disappointing sci-fi movie, like Gravity. It will probably be filled with all sorts of misconceptions about space, even though Kip Thorne has been the scientific consultant for it (and also executive producer). Remember the movie "Sunshine" from 2007? Brian Cox was the scientific consultant for that one, and yet the movie was filled with all sorts of misconceptions and inaccuracies that made me laugh. And what about Gravity? That unknown force that pulled Clooney away from the ISS was a total joke, same for the orbital nonsense between the Hubble, the ISS and the Russian satellites, etc. Just so you know, Interstellar tells the story of a group of astronauts who "travel" through a black hole...with hopes of going somewhere else and then return to Earth, that is. For all science knows, the laws of physics break down inside a black hole due to the tremendous gravitational pull, that means that we can't possibly know, through physics, what happens exactly to things that cross the "event horizon" (that's the edge of the black hole, so to speak). All science can tell for sure is that when something crosses the event horizon, there's no turning back, if you somehow managed to come out, it wouldn't be alive and in one piece. When Hawking talks about how it is possible for information to be preserved inside a black hole, it just means INFORMATION, in other words, the particles that form your body could still be "preserved" somehow but you would die nonetheless, all your atoms would be undone, and that isn't pretty. Whoever tells you that you can travel through black holes (survive the journey and come back to the same universe as if nothing happened, that is), doesn't have the math/mechanism to support this claim and Kip Thorne knows it. I bet all Kip has done is to help model the black hole, give direction to actors who will play scientist roles and perhaps a few more things, but I'm pretty sure this movie will still contain nonsense. Sci-fi directors usually claim they've made sure everything is scientifically accurate, showing us stuff like this> Interstellar ‚Äì Building A Black Hole ‚Äì Official Warner Bros. so people can say "Oh! This time they've got it right!" when, in reality, only some things are accurate, the rest is usually nonsense. Movies like Sunshine and Gravity are clear examples of this. Curiously, there is a 1968 movie called "2001: A Space Odyssey" (perhaps you've heard about it, LOL) that gets most things right, without the need of using unlikely black hole travel, without the need to sell it for its "realism" or scientific accuracy, without flashy special effects, absurd amounts of money and without being too pretentious. The non-scientific parts of that movie are highly symbolic, which make it even better. So Hollywood sci-fi movies nowadays have much larger budgets, a much higher availability of professionals from all branches, highly superior technology available, they generate much more money, etc. and yet they are worse every year... Why is that? I think it's because the essential guidelines of the business are wrong. They go for flashiness (big names, high numbers, extreme and flashy plots, etc.) instead of quality, they try to conciliate science with nonsensical extreme plots that are completely incompatible and absurd (my point being> don't try to sell the movie for its realism and accuracy if, in the end, it won't be so). This is the formula: big names + claims of scientific accuracy/realism + extreme plots filled with nonsense (the world is about to end, there's a critical accident/everything goes wrong, and the like) + stuff blowing up/getting destroyed + miraculous survivals + ultra hd cameras and all sorts of modern filters and effects + the hero saves the day (requiring his/her/their sacrifice, perhaps) = Next Hollywood sci-fi movie.

The crew was killed, he never came back. Well, that took 12 minutes to get to that point so this film will make more money per minute than any film before it. Oh, the film is continuing?... it has them LIVE?! WHAT!? NO WAY!? Oh look at all the pretty special effects. Ok, let's have the IMPOSSIBLE happen because Kip Thorne wants to be known as an Imagineer like Einstein was, he wants his legacy to be that he imagined further than his knowledge should have allowed, he was a hero. SO for that personal objective, we are now going to be fed a bag of worms about how people can survive going through a wormhole... oh great! So first he tries to teach us that engineers are obsolete, then he tries to teach us that science built this thing!?? NOPE TO BOTH. In the scenes they pull the power pack processing package from the Indian drone, as useful... oh wait, that's engineering. Then they say we ran out of food, what... did engineering fail to come up with solutions? NO WAY, engineers would have had people living where ever, with desalination wholesale, protected from radiation. Listen, if engineering can build a star ship to go exploring to move MILLIONS of people off this planet, the same engineering would have built the systems to remake a new place to live on Earth, probably under the sea! So this whole movie is based on... Kip Thorne playing around with his legacy. So yeah, they all die and the movie ends after 12 minutes. Let's all get refunds!! hehe

I love space movies, many of them are enthralling; I ardently respect all those astronauts who go to space and carry out experiments aboard the ISS. But, as a resident of this planet, I would love it if humanity would be less cruel to nature, and help maintain the balance of our ecosystem, by reducing pollution, violence, killing of animals. I am sure that no one will ever migrate to any other planet(Mars being the only option), because our body does not suit their atmosphere-if anyone goes on interplanetary travel, I am sure it will be a 1 way trip, and the whole world's population will never go, except astronauts & crazy billionaires. The Earth has life for a reason, no other planet has that, and we should be grateful for that. Wormholes are still a theory, but, if it is found to exist, interstellar travel will be carried out by astronauts only; 7 billion(who knows, 14 billion in the future) will never go and colonize on Alpha Beta whatever new planet that's discovered; we shall perish anyway due to geological events, maybe a massive earthquake, too much pollution, poisonous radiation from space etc. So, my point is, space travel should only be in fiction, novels and movies, and whatever NASA is doing, at least for now. It would be much useful for Earth & humanity's survival, if we concentrate on eradicating diseases, inventing a cure for all incurable diseases, reducing pollution of air/water/sound/land/electronic waste/radioactive waste etc., finding alternate ways of harnessing pollution free energy, letting animals live, and reducing violence, and lastly, doing all the mentioned work on a major scale(not like, only 20 cars run on electricity and the rest use gas) because, if the Earth survives, we do too-and the longer we live, the longer we can experiment on space travel. But Earth is our home and foundation, and we must not forget that.

I don't exactly know why this trailer makes me cry. I know I am saddened by war, world hunger, political corruption, and social injustice; our current social ills, hollow innovations, mindless celebrity worship, superficial ambitions, and social superiority. Perhaps this trailer makes me believe that humanity is still destined for things greater than those which so morbidly depress me. Perhaps it makes me believe that the age of discovery is not over, that the true spark of innovation still exists somewhere, that there's still a sense of wonder to relished in our efforts. Perhaps this why i cry, out of hope.

I don't understand why people find it hard to believe the reasoning behind us being an interstellar traveling species. During the existence of the Earth there have been over a handful of mass extinctions caused by different things. We have the technology and the means to survive some things, but the odds are that we will eventually have to just leave the planet. Let's say we find a way to prevent all those things, the sun is not going to last forever. Perfecting interstellar travel is the only way we can truly survive as a species. The ability to pick up our things and move to a different location is our only true means of survival, and you wouldn't want it to be the last thing you do before something catastrophic occurs. Chances are, by then it is too late.

replies.commentText: I agree. It's also important to note that both interplanetary and interstellar travel would allow life to express itself in far more ways than it can in its current state, trapped within the confines of Earth's gravity well. Life needs to be able to expand and grow; only then will we be able to experience life's adaptations to the most extreme environments. There's no telling what knowledge like this could unlock all of us.

Hard sci-fi lovers fear not! Theoretical physicist Kip Thorne (worm holes, time travel) wrote a script treatment that Jonathan Nolan adapted into a screenplay based on his scientific theories. Thorne, Chris Nolan, & Co. know what they're doing; we can barely put together a premise based on these trailers, which is a good thing imo. It's been a while since a movie has blown me away and I think this one might be swinging for the fences.

If you see the casting at IMDB, you can see that there is Young Murph (Mackenzie Foy), Murph at a midle age (Jessica Chastain) and old Murph (Ellen Burstyn), this last one prorbably will play Murph when she ¬¥s more than 70 years old......same thing for Tom, played at a midle age by Casey Affleck and as an old man by William Devane.........This is going to be Epic.....In Nolan We Trust!!

the idea behind this film is simple, the ability to use a wormhole to jump to another planet and find a livable environment is perfectly plausible, though highly unlikely, and depending on the development of technology and the plausibility of being able to colonize mars and sustain that would not be plausible at all, we have technology to make that work for some time, but not for the 50+years this film is seeming to aim at. Interstellar travel is a fact of live and will happen eventually assuming our race evolves enough and the parameters of physics happen, due to the high likelihood that the ability of earth to sustain us as lifeforms will end. and while we may not know exactly how wormholes work in every facet, they do seem to be the best option in terms of interstellar travel out there due to the distances between solar systems being to great. this movie isn't silly, nor is it illogical based on the parameters it gives, its just exploring a thought path that we will probably explore one day. also as far as the food problem, that could very easily happen based on solar emission spectra changing in the slightest manner due to the core composition of our sun changing, so no it is not stupid, please stop talking as if you know everything in the field of astrophysics and biology, life isnt that simple.

"We don't need engineers on Earth". Seriously? I totally want to see us go to space, but can we PLEASE stop this bull about the planet being a train wreck, and we have to get off the train? Yes, I get that they want to have a 'compelling' reason to go to space, but what about doing it as a voyage of discovery? Are we too cynical these days? There are lots of good reasons to go to space that have nothing to do with the planet 'dying'. Such as gathering resources (even in our own solar system); there are trillions of dollars worth of resources (various metals) in the form of asteroid mining, or Helium 3 extraction, etc. That would create jobs, and do a hell of a lot for certain resource scarcities.

replies.commentText: In this movie the world didnt need any more engineers.
That is a fallacy. There is always a need for engineers, even if all they do is fix complicated machinery, i.e. maintenance.

"The world doesn't need more engineers" Which implies that it has enough, and they won't be enough to save them. It implies they need something more. They never said anywhere that engineers are useless.

Well that is fine as far as it goes. Still, there is ZERO evidence that the Earth is dying and that IS a valid reason to be annoyed at that continuously perpetuated myth. Climate change has been going on for billions of years, and it isn't about to stop. We humans definitely need to stop making messes, but we aren't killing the planet wholesale. If the Earth really got ticked off at us, it could wipe us out and start over, no biggie. So to speak. I just get annoyed with the 'humans are causing the Earth to turn into a colossal desert' scenario. It is a myth used by certain folks to dupe the gullible with eco-guilt. That doesn't mean I'm against clean tech, but we need to do it for valid reasons. Not for the mythological hype.

In this theory the spaceship contracts space in front of it and expands space behind it. which can be used to travel faster than light without experiencing g-force. I wish this film the best of success. I hope it opens up a serious debate about our declining resources, our environment, and our survival as a species. However, here is a question. Why in the trailer (and I strongly assume in the film) there is technology that can help a spaceship travel at those great distances in space, but no technology that can reverse hunger, climate change, etc?

replies.commentText: Because sometimes nature is not in our control, like tsunami, typhoons etc. In the movie the situation is that the earth's surface became so toxic that no food can grow from it except corn (assuming from trailer). The technological gaps have always been in several domains.

Because those are 2 entirely different technical problems, and the fact that they're both very difficult does not mean that they are both equally solvable. For one thine, while Interstellar travel is strictly an engineering and physics problem, "feeding the world" is far more than that. It's also a social and a political problem. Human technology has never, ever been anywhere near as effectual at dealing with sociology or politics, as it has with dealing with mere physical laws. There may very well be in fact a solution to the problem of interstellar flight, and yet no solution whatsoever to the problem of feeding billions of people systematically on earth. Especially under extremely adverse conditions, involving the total breakdown of all existing agricultural systems, and the social chaos that almost certainly comes with that, which is what this trailer implies is going on in that movie.

+Trialtrex21 why does everyone think it's a black hole? Google image search event horizon. We don't know what a worm hole looks like because we don't know if it even exists. We can predict that an event horizon looks exactly like what's shown haha.

+melonfarmer The problem with your suggestion of it being a black hole is that the center of the object near the end is not, well, black. According to current theories, a black hole would suck in all light, so the center would be pitch black. The object near the end of the trailer, however, is just a mass of warped light.

+Trialtrex21 The event horizon is not a thing. It's a point in time. When you're at the event horizon, you're about to enter the black hole but not quite. The image shown is not what the black hole looks like, but what and individual see's looking out of the event horizon

IMDB credits Jessica Chastain as 'Murph' and the child actress as 'Young Murph'

1:54 is not an event horizon. An event horizon is the point of no return of a black hole(among others) where nothing can escape the gravitational pull. What we can see at 1:54 i believe is an Alcubierre drive which is suppose to contract space in front of you and expanding space behind you thus achieving faster than light speeds, so IMO that plot is not a valid one.

+Argentin Iacob The time travel and chastain as the older murph are confirmed (and obvious in the trailer), so, regardless on how accurate you feel the terminology is, the plot is valid in the context of what we know about the film.
kinda like star trek 2009 when Spock goes through the black hole in seconds and Niro waited 25 years for him

+Cody Lakin I'll take black holes over the inevitable extinction of our universe that will leave us starless and in the dark. At least we don't know what happens in a black hole and at least we can theorize that it is a gateway.

+melonfarmer I really hope you're wrong about the plot, what the trailer promotes has far more potential than a touchy feely catch up story. I want to see something suggested, something that stimulates the imagination, not a story summed up in its run time.
+hotsauce3888 From what I can tell, there will most likely be much more to the story than that.
+Trialtrex21 Please be right

+melonfarmer No, it is not a time, it is a location. The event horizon is the point in which the gravity is so powerful that light cannot escape the warping on space-time. It has a border and that border is where light cannot escape from the gravity well.

+Argentin Iacob I REALLY hope it's an Alcubierre drive. A wormhole would be a bit contrived, and the spacecraft seems built with the toroidal placement of mass-energy density consistent with an Alcubierre drive as proposed by Dr. Harold Sonny White, plus what's shown isn't consistent with a black hole or white hole, though it may be a wormhole. Both a wormhole and the Alcubierre metric are GR solutions for apparent superluminal travel, so they'd look much the same, the difference is we could generate an Alcubierre warp bubble. Freakishly beautiful, though. I'm obsessed with the Alcubierre drive and really excited to see I'm not the only one! I'm also really curious about some details. Do you know much about it?

+Cirrus Light Sorry to disappoint you, but i have a superficial understanding of it (Alcubierre drive), which involves almost no math. I can understand equations and follow the reasoning behind the idea but in a conceptual way. That's why i think of mathematicians and especially physicists as superhumans (just think of Einstens theories and how mind blowing they are). And this Alcubierre drive is such an elegant way of bypassing the maximum speed limit imposed by GR, given all the conditions are met.

+Samsonite Man ...said the man that likes hammy dialog of Japanese Anime.

Couple of things: To react on both the emptiness and the ambition: I think Christopher Nolan quite often use big ideas that can be quite hard to grasp and sometimes just seems like a complicated bunch of ideas,his movies really make a difference if you watch his movies several times, and you really do have to pay attention. I can perfectly understand you didn't enjoy inception if you slept through a part of it, after that it will be rather impossible to keep up with it.I usually that his movies get more effective emotionally the better you understand them, the easiast example of that is "the prestige", which you can easily watch twice if you haven't watched it before, after the revelation (or the prestige as you wish), some dialogue that seemed like pretty random banter becomes really powerful and painful really. Nolan is absolutely no "champion of marketing cinephilia", I do love his trailers, but the way it's promoted doesn't show a lot.You seem to forget that both the Prestige and Inception didn't make that much money.The Dark Knight Rises probably was his most anticipated movie, it also wasn't the movie he didn't really wanted to make, as far as I heard he actually wanted to make a movie about Howard Hughes (that's why Bruce Wayne is a mad cripple in the beginning of the movie, there's not even that much batman in the entire movie anyway).The most horrible marketing stuff happened (as you probably know) with "the Amazing Spiderman 2" of which the trailers included: the final shot of the movie, a villain that pops up only near the end and worst of all things that aren't even in the movie. I do have to say, because of Chris Nolan (or actually,his succes) quite a lot of bad things have started: all big movies now seem to be dark and gritty and 2,5 hours long but since they usually lack the ideas Nolan's movies have they just end up with a third act where I just did not care. Since Inception movies are quite often become just clever for being clever, also the trailer BWRAAAAAM, getting sick of it (actually not composed by Hans Zimmer).And to pick two things at once: Hans Zimmer, I think the guy is great and I think his work with Christopher Nolan hasn't been anything but wonderful (just look at the succeses of the soundtracks of the batman movies (especially Joker's theme and the "Deshi Deshi Bashara Bashara" were really big), the more or less hype that Inception had about it's soundtrack (mostly a "dream is collapsing" and "Time"),I won't go into detail what I personnaly like so much about it), but I have to say: the man seems to be doing every big movie nowadays, and then he just seems to do nothing but typical Hans Zimmer stuff. "The true science fiction is philosophical, acurate, complete, emotional, beautiful, epic and there is a developped universe" absolutely "To me, Inception and this Interstellar are thriller movies, not science fiction" Inception is both, Interstellar isn't even out yet but it doesn't seem to be any different, essentially sci-fi is about ideas that are not (yet) possible, the dream thing is one of those and there's no way we could place that story in a more realistic setting. p.s. I do expect a proper answer to this, at first I felt just like saying that you're simply wrong. Also I don't need you to suddenly like Nolan's work, just have a bit more respect for him.

First of all, to say that Nolan's movies have no ambition is a flat out lie. To watch Inception and see the technical mastery put in to place in that movie and say that it is not ambitious, is just naive. Secondly, just because you define "true science fiction" is that does not mean that it is what science fiction is. ALSO, you say that science fiction is "accurate." However, some of the best science fiction movies ARE NOT ACCURATE! Star Wars (arguably science fantasy but whatever), Star Trek, and several other famous sci-fi franchises are all scientifically wrong because they have NOISE IN SPACE! All those lasers blasting in to space would not make a sound. So therefore they aren't science fiction? Please. You don't get to define science fiction as that when it throws out almost the entire genre. Also, science fiction movies don't have to be EPIC. They can be low key and still be great. And how can you have a "developed universe" without establishing it in a movie. All I am seeing here is someone who doesn't like Nolan is trying to justify it by sounding smart or clever.

Hey VashJohny - a) Don't you think it is a bit premature to judge something you have not seen yet? It's like trying to shit out something you have not eaten - can be kinda difficult. b) you probably meant of Nolan being an over-rated director, not an "overestimated" one - unless you are a teenager trying out to look smart. c) give an example of " philosophical, acurate, complete, emotional, beautiful, epic and there is a developped universe" sci-fi movie, 'cause I have not seen such a thing. There are no perfect movies out there. Has never been. And likely will never be. What IS important is to have a VARIETY of different sci-fi movies for different people with different tastes to get entertained. I might decide that I like "Interstellar" (when I see it), while "Godzilla" or "Jupiter Ascending" might be more to your liking. Which is OK. But - if I were you - I would not opine about a movie I have not seen, especially based on a trailer that does not reveal much. Unless you are one of stupid people who have nothing better to do.

Did you know that 99% of the genetic information in you is not human? It's the genetic information of your symbiotic bacteria and virii, without which you could not survive. Now if a human was transported to the surface of a living alien world, and he was immersed in alien bacteria and virii, what would happen to him? Nothing good, I'll bet. On the other hand - even if we had the prerequisite technology for a manned interstellar expedition (we don't), such an expedition would require international co-operation, and it would be fantastically expensive. But to reduce carbon emissions to a point at which climate change would be stabilized would also require international co-operation, and it would be - much less expensive. Hmmm. So what, after all, is the point of this vile, vulgar and escapist tripe?

commentText: From what I gather, the story/plot is about a last-ditch effort to preserve the human race by using experimental space technology which does work in theory but, is currently still in the developmental stages by scientists. First, in the preview there appears to be some sort of safe and advanced cryogenic-hibernation or stasis. Secondly, Nuclear Fusion type rocket propulsion would be necessary to reach Saturn's orbit in a reasonable time-frame. Lastly, this safe distance from the Earth would be required in order to activate the very first experimental Alcubierre drive which (in theory) creates a warp-bubble around a spacecraft allowing it to safely break the light-barrier and reach other solar systems. I'm not an astrophysicist, I'm just desperate to leave this planet.

This is what I think the plot is: Humanity faces extinction from starvation. The sun has become too unstable to sustain life on Earth for much longer. However, a wormhole has been discovered, and Earth's governments decide to send a team through the wormhole to discover where it leads to. If it is safe, humanity will begin a mass exodus through the wormhole. The main character is an engineer and a pilot, which makes him suitable for such a mission. He has two children, a daughter and a son, which he loves very much. He leaves on the mission unwillingly, promising his children that he will come back. However, years has passed. The main character's children has now grown up (Jessica Chastain plays his grown up daughter, note the similarity between the two) and Earth is in much more dire situation. The main character and his mission has not returned and the children starts looking for answers.

+Barky Von Schnauzer Nature is a destructive force. Humans are the evolution of life on the planet to it's current highest state... in essence we are a continuation of that destructive force. We destroy, we create, we destroy. It's the pattern of life; and only a fool would assume we are someone not connected to it eternally. That doesn't mean we don't have choices, it just means our choices are always going to be geared toward surviving and prospering. If that means using up every resource on the planet to do that...well yeah...we will and that will spur the need to move on. Okay so now you are thinking 'Well we don't have a right to do that!!'... but you see nature and the very path of our creation on this planet WANTED us to do just that. Imagine this...if you were stranded on a dessert island and you knew you would have to use up EVERY scrap of resources on that island to live until you were rescued, would you? Or would you just roll over and die. If you think you would just die, you are deluding yourself.

For the simple fact of the matter is, the planet Earth is doomed... Let us follow many environmentalists and regard the Earth as Gaia, the mother of all life (which indeed she is). +The Ayala Factor Just to clarify, they're not going into a black hole, their space ship essentially creates a tiny one, or a singularity, to warp space-time, which allows for faster than light travel. Nothing could survive a black hole, nothing made of matter at least, the gravity of a black hole would rip the ship and its occupants apart down to the individual atoms. This movie is based on real scientific theory. And though some black hole theories account for the possibility of traveling vast distances of the universe if one went through it, all one has to do is account for the sheer gravitational power of the black hole beyond the event horizon to know that its just not possible. Hope that adds more clarity to you.

Interesting concept for interstellar travel! But.....the earth will never run out of food. I saw a lot of burning cornfields in this preview. But.....there are other sources of food, both animal and vegetable. Not all of the Entire World's food comes from midwestern cornfields! If you live in a vacuum and have never travelled the world you might think that what Hollywood says could be accurate. But it is not. The whole premise behind Interstellar Travel should be to explore other worlds, gather resources, and build space-faring communities, not to escape the planet Earth. If you were to dispose of the intriguing scenes where they are in space, what you are left with is a movie that sounds like the Kurt Russell flop: "Escape from L.A.", only on a global scale. The Earth is beautiful my friends, and there are many many people who are actually succeeding at keeping it that way.

Sure, brilliant idea Warner Bro's Studios! Lets just take planet Earth and do what we have always done with things we don't want: throw it away! Trash it! So we can move on to the next thing or planet in this case, and throw it away when the time comes too! I don't think enough people understand just how valuable something like a planet like Earth is. Is it any small wonder we haven't found any other planets out there readily capable of supporting life? Planets like Earth may be the most valuable thing in the Universe! It literally mean the world to you, and me. Ugh. The premise of this movie makes me sick. Heads up though; we are indeed short on engineers, companies can't get enough of them! What we do have too much of though is PEOPLE and I don't think there will be an end to how much food we can salvage/produce. Nonetheless this looks like an entertaining and interesting movie. Its just the idea's that its based on that makes me worry.

For all those who are saying it's a worm hole, it is not. It's depicting warp drive as proven mathematically possible by Miguel Alcubierre. We use immense amounts of energy to compress space-time in front of a craft and expand it behind it. This make faster-than-light travel possible because we move space-time, not the space craft.

A film critique made a good point about Christopher Nolan's films. What Nolan does best is make films about complex subject matters and ideas, and make them appeal to a mass audience. So he adds the spectacle of the grand score, visuals and performances, but doesn't treat his audience like idiots. While we have films like Transformers 4 coming out which looks like just a series of explosions, Nolan will probably give his audience something to engage their minds with. :)

I hate to be the bummer bunny here, but this is not an original concept by a long shot. Inception was, and as a result not much else mattered -- people were captivated. This film doesn't have the same going for it. The concept has been done and done again. Rather than riding on a gimmick or original idea, this film's success rides on everything else: acting, screenplay, cinematography, etc. It also helps that everyone thinks so highly of Nolan. If this were by another director most people would just yawn. I don't think it will be anything special, but it would be great to be proven wrong.

Yeah... The plot/story sound kind of generic, but I'm sure that what we're seeing here is just 1/3. Nolan was quoted saying that with this one he is honoring 2001, this one looks more conventional than that but it's the director of Inception we're talking about (ability to take generic plot and inject interesting concepts and ideas into it). I know it's early but cinematography looks gorgeous, i was kind of skeptical since he's working with new DP in this one but Hoytema is more then a fine replacement, angles, colors... everything looks beautiful but let's not get ahead of our selves. I would love it if this is pretty much all the information we would get about this movie, i get that it's impossible since everyone depends on this one to be a hit (WB gave up two of their major franchise's just so they could get a cut of the cake, two major studios WB and Paramout are together in this, Legendary pic. bowed out of Man of Steel just so they can finance this one, how much this one earns will in my opinion define Nolan's future career since TDK films and Inception had all batman hype around it, if this one is indeed what Nolan claims it to be and is really that popular it would mean that Nolan is to stay and that more 'not so dumb but kind of emotionless' movies are on the way). I can't wait but I'm kind of afraid since the last time i had huge hopes for a Nolan movie i was kind of disappointed (The Dark Knight Rises... you can't really say it's his fault but Man of Steel too, and big time...)

Looks like a a movie confronting issues of science and economics. The issues I can see on the trailer is earth is running out of food due to some natural or man made disaster involving massive dust storms similar to those of the Great Depression. The line " the world doesn't need anymore engineers...... we ran out of food" is small reference to the fact that IRL the world is running out of farmers. The government is sending people to other star systems to look for habitable worlds. I can see the use of hypersleep, some kind of space traveling device that bends space-time most likely an Alcubierre warp drive. I'm excited to finally see a movie about the potential, adventure, and discoveries of the first interstellar travel by mankind. Something I feel is the most important issue for the future and survival of humanity.

commentText: The worm hole as seen in this trailer is a depiction of Dr. Kip Thorne's theories of a spinning black hole. Kip is a world renowned Caltech Physicist and leader of wormhole theory. Nolan brought him on as an exec prod for the film and He is taking my breath away. Not only does he depict the most realistic future apocalypse with climate change destroying soil and producing dust bowls, but he is giving us a realistic glimpse into real theoretical interstellar travel. This man knows no equal when it comes to truly inspirational a moving tales. As was so eloquently said decade ago, he is "inspiring the imagination of a generation".

Yet another silly Hollywood mess that demonstrates a complete ignorance of science and how it would be applied to avert crisis. Set to the tune of millions of wasted dollars. If we run into the problem of critical food shortage, and we very well may, a more prudent solution would be to apply vertical farms. There are nations out there building them today. (Sadly, none of those nations are America.) We wouldn't wait until the problem has created a global dust-bowl dystopia then send a single crew to another planet. That solution, while it makes for pretty visuals and an entertaining, if silly story, is asinine. I encourage people genuinely concerned with global food shortage to check out vertical farming, and particularly a book written by Mr. Diamandis and Mr. Kotler entitled: "Abundance". I'll see this movie in theaters, but I'll bring my own grain of salt.

The characters look like they live in a very near future, BUT the technology being used to travel through black holes is not even close to reality. 2) Humanity is converging and things like stopping the population growth would be acted on way before there was no more food. Plus science will grow food way before humanity can travel long distances through space. Smh. 3) In the future when humanity might act on such a desperate decision, THEY as "we humanity" will not resemble a person today. This isn't about wormhole's or blackhole's the spaceship in the video seems to use a warp drive, and the visual effects of bending space are what you might expect things to look if NASA is successful with thier warp drive project - http://www.extremetech.com/extreme/164326-nasa-discusses-its-warp-drive-research-prepares-to-create-a-warp-bubble-in-the-lab The currently proposed spacecrafts to warp space have torus rings around them, just like the spacecraft in the vid. Also NASA has estimated with a warp drive compressing space in front of the craft and expanding it behind the craft we could travel to Alpha Centauri, the nearest solar system in 2 weeks to 2-3 months. So in all likelihood the space travelers in this film would come back from a successful trip relatively soon.

Funny with all these global warming apocalyptic movies, in which mankind wants to leave Earth in search of a new home... #1) We are accepting that we are ruining Earth, yet we don't do anything to fix it (and I mean, now, today, in the real Earth right here). We make the mess, then we want to leave to #2: make the exact same mess in a new world. Accept it. The human being will always be greedy, voracious, careless, selfish, no matter where it goes. We have it in our genes. The first thing that we'll do in another planet is look for gold, then pick the best place, make frontiers, and prohibit anybody else from getting to those resources. Humanity has no unity because we can't share, we want it all, and we'll always consider ourselves worthier and better that the others.

Science fiction and even popular culture, when on the topic of space, seems preoccupied with life on other planets and/or getting to the stars. I have a theory; as we continue to explore and get more acquainted with our solar system, the focus of science fiction and popular culture will begin to shift from the stars and turn to the wonders of our solar system and how man can travel within the system. I call it growing up and I figure we should start seeing this shift 20 years from now.

This movie is NOT about environmentalism, not at its core. It's essentially about the "Space Manifest Destiny." I believe this movie focuses on the battle between science and conservatism, a.k.a "Why do we do we need to spend so much on science when we can't fix our own problems today?" Considering the continual budget cuts for NASA (despite them spending less than 1/50th of the spending on military resources), it's quite the contemporary piece

I had been anticipating this trailer for such a long time, and it was a partial reason why I went to see Godzilla last night, so I could see the new trailer on the big screen. This movie is going to be the best of 2014, I can feel it. It has so much going for it. Nolan's craft and perfection with his movies is like no one else's; his unique style will be breathtaking. (He's already warned theaters that the sound design and output will be like nothing else before.) I can Interstellar winning 10 Oscars next February including a second consecutive Best Actor for MM. I will be in Boston at the time of this release and I hope to attend a big midnight premiere! I won't be sleeping much come October! The excitement is here!

It's trying to be a more realistic portrayal of a possible near future rather than a more abstract concept of the far future that Mass Effect 3 was. Most likely this is to push the overall message of seeing what humanity will do in its final moments to save itself. Push it too far into the future and we become easily capable of moving planets and the tension won't be nearly as high. Still, it looks like they are making some cool-looking ship and tech concepts for the movie.
Things can't always be what we want them to be, but shit, it doesn't mean the movie is gonna be bad. The Mass Effect style would be cool though.

lol. why though? I'm fan of the games, but space opera is played out, and the Mass Effect universe is hardly unique or interesting within that genre. You have all these "aliens" that are basically humans with different shit glued onto their forehead. It's more fantasy than scifi.
Why? Movies styled like video games almost always fail.

Well many directors, when they work for long periods of time, may use different cinematographers. Spielberg has used many different DPs (Although he has been using Kaminski ever since Schindler's List), as has Scorsese, just to name two. I look forward to seeing a differently shot film that still has all the trademarks and tropes of his work.

True, true, though I'm very interested to see if Nolan will continue to use a different cinematographer or go back to wally pfister after this movie. I assume that the only reason wally pfister isn't on this one is due to his commitment as director of transcendence. Nolan has used the same editor, composer and cinematographer on his last number of films.
